conclusion: The problem involves analyzing a circuit with a power supply (E = 10V), two capacitors (C1 = C2 = 30μF), two resistors (R1 = 4.0Ω, R2 = 6.0Ω), and a switch (S). The task is to calculate the amount of charge passing through R1 after S is opened.
The circuit consists of a power supply connected in series with R1 and R2. C1 and C2 are connected in parallel with R1 and R2, respectively. The switch S is in parallel with R2 and C2.
When the switch S is closed, the circuit forms a single loop with R1 and R2 in series. When the switch S is opened, the capacitors discharge through the resistors.
The total resistance in the circuit when S is closed is R1 + R2 = 4.0Ω + 6.0Ω = 10.0Ω.
The current in the circuit when S is closed is I = E / (R1 + R2) = 10V / 10.0Ω = 1A.
The voltage across R2 is U = I × R2 = 1A × 6.0Ω = 6V.
The charge on capacitor C1 when S is closed is Q1 = C1 × U = 30μF × 6V = 1.8 × 10⁻⁴C.
After the switch S is opened, the capacitors are directly connected to the power supply, and the voltage across each capacitor equals the electromotive force of the power supply.
The charge on each capacitor after S is opened is Q2 = C × E = 30μF × 10V = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴C.

premise: Charge on each capacitor after S is opened = Q2 = 3.0 × 10⁻⁴C, Charge on C1 when S was closed = Q1 = 1.8 × 10⁻⁴C
conclusion: The amount of charge flowing through R1 after S is opened is ΔQ = 2 × Q2 - Q1 = 2 × 3.0 × 10⁻⁴C - 1.8 × 10⁻⁴C = 4.2 × 10⁻⁴C.
